introduction.p: We consider more examples of orthogonal decomposition, and then apply this concept to prove that certain linear manifolds are dense.

section.title: Properties of orthogonal projection
section.p: Last time we found that for every x\in Hi and any linear subspace \Mi there is a closest element of \Mi, denoted P_{\Mi}x, and that x-P_{\Mi}x \in \Mi\perp. Another way to describe P_{\Mi}x is: the unique element x'\in M such that x - x'\in M^\perp.

Some properties of orthogonal projection:
P_{\Mi} is linear, meaning P_{\Mi}(\alpha x+\beta y) = \alpha P_{\Mi}(x) + \beta P_{\Mi}(y)
\|P_{\Mi}(x)-P_{\Mi}(y)\|\le \|x-y\| for all x, y \in \Hi.
We also have P_{\Mi^\perp} = I - P_{\Mi} where I is the identity map.

section.title: Examples of orthogonal decomposition and projection
section.p: In the space \Hi = \ell^2 let \Mi be the set of all sequences such that x(2k)=0 for every k. What is its orthogonal complement \Mi^\perp? How does P_{\Mi} work?
In the space \Hi = L^2([0, 1]) let \Mi be the set of all constant functions. What is \Mi^\perp? How does P_{\Mi} work?
In the space \Hi = L^2([-\pi, \pi]) let \Mi be the set of all even functions. What is \Mi^\perp? How does P_{\Mi} work?

section.title: Dense linear manifolds
section.p: A subset E\subset \Hi is dense if its closure \overline{E} is all of \Hi.
Claim: for any subspace E we have \overline{E}^\perp = E^\perp. The reason is the continuity of inner product with respect to each argument.
If A is a linear manifold, then its closure \overline{A} is a linear subspace.

A typical way to prove that a linear manifold A of \Hi is dense is to show that A^\perp = \{0\}. Indeed, if A is not dense, then its closure would be a proper linear subspace, and that would have a nontrivial orthogonal complement.

Examples:
c_{00} is dense in \ell^2
The space S of simple functions (those that attain finitely many values) is dense in L^2([a, b]). Idea of proof: suppose f\in S^\perp \setminus \{0\} and use the Lebesgue differentiation theorem to find a simple function g (the characteristic function \chi_I of some interval I) such that \inn{f, g}\ne 0.
The space of all continuous functions on [a, b], denoted C([a, b]), is also dense in L^2([a, b]). Similar strategy works, with \chi_I replaced by a triangular bump function.
